The Bulletin of the European Union reports on the activities of the Commission and the other Community institutions. It is produced by the Secretariat-General of the European Commission and published 10 times a year in the official European languages. The following reference system is used: the first digit indicates the part number, the second digit the chapter number and the subsequent digit or digits the point number. Citations should therefore read as follows: Bull. 1/2-1994, point 1.1.1 or 2.2.3. The Bulletin is also available on the Europa server (http://europa.eu.int/abc/doc/off/bull/en/welcome.htm). A great deal of additional information on the European Union is available on the Internet. It can be accessed through the Europa server (http://europa.eu.int). 8 Bull. EU 1/2-2006 1. Institutional questions Treaty establishing a Constitution for Europe 1.1.1. Ratification by Belgium. Approved by the parliamentary method on 8 February. 1.1.2. European Parliament resolution on the period of reflection: the structure, subjects and context for an assessment of the debate on the European Union. References: European Parliament resolution on the Treaty establishing a Constitution for Europe: OJ C 247 E, 6.10.2005; Bull. 1/2-2005, point 1.1.1 Commission communication — ‘The Commis- sion’s contribution to the period of reflection and beyond: Plan D for democracy, dialogue and debate’ — Bull. 10-2005, point 1.1.3 Committee of the Regions opinion: Bull. 10- 2005, point 1.1.4 European Economic and Social Committee opin- ion: Bull. 10-2005, point 1.1.5 Adopted on 19 January. The European Parliament has declared it its duty and that of the national parliaments, to contribute to the period of reflec- tion on the constitutional future of Europe. Con- vinced that the Treaty of Nice is not a viable basis for the continuation of the European integration process, it confirms its determination to achieve a constitutional settlement which strengthens par- liamentary democracy, transparency and the rule of law, anchors fundamental rights, develops cit- izenship, and enhances the capacity of the Union to act effectively both at the internal level and on the international scene. It thus proposes that the conclusions of the period of reflection be formu- lated during the second half of 2007 and all pos- sible efforts be made to guarantee that the Con- stitution will enter into force in 2009. In addition, it believes that a positive outcome of the period of reflection would be that the current text be maintained, although this would only be possible if accompanied by significant measures to reas- sure and convince public opinion. Governance 1.1.3. European Economic and Social Commit- tee own-initiative opinion — ‘The representation of European organisations in civil society within the framework of citizen dialogue’ ( → point 1.1.3). Interinstitutional cooperation 1.1.4. Council conclusions on the Court of Audi- tors’ report on interpretation expenditure in- curred by the Parliament, the Commission and the Council. Reference: Special Report No 5/2005 of the Court of Auditors: Bull. 9-2005, point 1.9.6 Adopted on 14 February. The Council welcomed the Court’s special report on interpretation expen- diture incurred by three institutions and consid- ered it very useful as the audit covers the period of the accession of 10 new Member States, increasing the number of official and working languages to 21. It noted with satisfaction that the institutions have been successful in containing interpretation expenditure, but regretted that a sub- stantial amount has been spent for interpretation services requested but not used because of late meeting cancellations. The Council recommended that efforts be made to reduce these cancellations, underlining that further savings are possible. The Council stressed the need to maintain the high quality of interpretation provided in the institu- tions, as well as the availability of interpretation services in all languages, while controlling costs. It agreed that procedures to avoid the provision of interpretation services exceeding real require- ments are an absolute necessity for all institutions. Finally, the Council asked for an independent evaluation concerning the possible costs and ben- efits of the creation of one single interinstitutional office providing interpretation services to all EU institutions, compared with those achieved by increased interinstitutional cooperation.

Bull. EU 1/2-2006 9 2. Lisbon strategy Lisbon strategy 1.2.1. European Parliament resolution on the future of the Lisbon strategy from the point of view of the gender perspective ( → point 1.8.2). 1.2.2. Communication from the Commission to the Council, the European Parliament, the Euro- pean Economic and Social Committee and the Committee of the Regions — ‘Implementing the Community Lisbon programme: fostering entre- preneurial mindsets through education and learn- ing ( → point 1.11.2). 1.2.3. Committee of the regions opinion on Commission communication ‘i2010 — A Euro- pean information society for growth and employ- ment’ ( → point 1.2.3). 1.2.4. Communication from the Commission to the European Council on ‘Implementing the renewed partnership for growth and jobs — Developing a knowledge flagship: the European Institute of Technology’ ( → point 1.2.4). 1.2.5. Communication from the Commission to the spring European Council — ‘Time to deliver — The new partnership for growth and jobs’. Reference: Conclusions of the Lisbon European Council: Bull. 3-2000, points I.3 to I.19 Previous report: Communication from the Com- mission to the spring 2005 European Council — ‘Time to deliver — The new partnership for growth and jobs’: COM(2005) 24; Bull. 1/2-2005, point 1.1.4 Adopted on 25 January. The Commission submit- ted its annual report on the Lisbon strategy which is devoted to achieving increased growth and employment. There are three main elements in the progress report. The Commission analysed the 25 new national reform programmes submitted by Member States in October 2005, and noted the strong points in each national programs with a view to promoting the exchange of good ideas between Member States. The report highlights the sectors in which there are shortcomings and proposes con- crete actions in the hope of remedying them, at both the European Union and national levels. In addi- tion, the Commission defines four priority action areas: investing more in knowledge and innovation; unlocking the business potential, particularly of small and medium-sized enterprises; delivering more and better jobs in the face of globalisation and ageing; moving towards an efficient and integrated EU energy policy. For each of these areas, the Com- mission’s report makes clear proposals for Euro- pean leaders to commit to when they next meet. COM(2006) 30 1.2.6. Proposal for a European Parliament and Council regulation on the application of the pro- visions of the Aarhus Convention on access to information, public participation and access to jus- tice in environmental matters to European Com- munity institutions and bodies ( → point 1.20.22).

10 Bull. EU 1/2-2006 3. Information and communication General aspects 1.3.1. White Paper on a European communica- tion policy. Adopted on 1 February. In the hope that commu- nication becomes a real European Union informa- tion policy, the Commission proposed to reform its own communication activities, in order to get closer to citizens and to be more responsive to their concerns. The main purpose of the White Paper is to mobilise all key actors (EU institutions and bodies, Member States, regional and local author- ities, political parties and civil society). This White Paper proposes five areas where joint action should be taken: defining common principles for com- munication on European issues, empowering citi- zens, working with the media and new technolo- gies, understanding public opinion, and doing the job together. At the end of the six-month consul- tation period, the Commission will summarise the replies and draw conclusions, with a view to pro- posing plans of action for each working area. The proposals to create a European press agency with the modernisation of what already exists, and a European Institute for Teacher Training, are both included in this document, which moreover sug- gests appointing goodwill ambassadors from the cultural, academic and sporting elite of Europe. Bull. EU 1/2-2006 11 4. Human rights Actions within the European Union 1.4.1. European Parliament declaration on child helplines in Europe. Adopted on 17 January. Parliament recommended that the European Union support child helplines as an essential part of the child protection system and that child helplines have a common toll-free telephone number. Parliament also called for EU cooperation with NGOs in setting up helpline net- works and in policy development. 1.4.2. European Parliament resolution on homo- phobia in Europe. References: Council Directive 2000/43/EC implementing the principle of equal treatment between persons irre- spective of racial or ethnic origin: OJ L 180, 19.7.2000; Bull. 6-2000, point 1.3.19 Council Directive 2000/78/EC establishing a general framework for equal treatment in employ- ment and occupation: OJ L 303, 2.12.2000; Bull. 11-2000, point 1.3.19 Charter of fundamental rights of the European Union: OJ C 364, 18.12.2000; Bull. 12-2000, point 1.2.2 Adopted on 18 January. Parliament called for action at EU and national levels to eradicate homo- phobia and promote a culture of freedom, tolerance and equality among citizens and in legal systems. It condemned any discrimination on the basis of sexual orientation and recommends to step up the fight against homophobia through education as well as through administrative, judicial and legislative means. Parliament also called on Member States to ensure that lesbian, homosexual, bisexual and trans- gender (LGBT) persons are protected from homo- phobic hate speech and violence and to ensure that same-sex partners enjoy the same respect, dignity and protection as the rest of society. 1.4.3. European Parliament decision setting up a temporary committee on the alleged use of Euro- pean countries by the CIA for the transportation and illegal detention of prisoners. Reference: European Parliament resolution on the presumed use of European countries by the CIA for the transportation and illegal detention of pris- oners: Bull. 12-2005, point 1.2.7 Adopted on 18 January. Parliament decided to set up a temporary committee to accompany the enquiry pending at the Council of Europe on the presumed use of European countries by the CIA for the transportation and illegal detention of pris- oners. The committee will collect and analyse information to find out whether the CIA or other US agents or intelligence services of other third countries have carried out abductions, ‘extraordi- nary rendition’, detention at secret sites, deten- tion incommunicado or torture or other cruel, inhuman or degrading treatment of prisoners on the territory of the European Union, including accession and candidate countries, or have used that territory to those ends, for example through flights. The committee will also attempt to deter- mine whether Member States, public officials, persons acting in an official capacity or European Union institutions have been involved or com- plicit in the alleged offences. Parliament asked the committee to submit any recommendations to the plenary and to present an interim report to Parliament within four months after it has started its work. 1.4.4. European Parliament resolution on the cur- rent situation in combating violence against women and for any future action. References: Parliament resolution on the need to establish a European Union-wide campaign for zero tolerance of violence against women: OJ C 304, 6.10.1997; Bull. 9-1997, point 1.1.10 Parliament resolution on the follow-up to the Beijing action platform: OJ C 59, 23.2.2001; Bull. 5-2000, point 1.3.24 Parliament resolution on female genital mutila- tion: OJ C 77 E, 28.3.2002; Bull. 9-2001, point 1.2.3 European Parliament resolution on the follow-up to the Fourth World Conference on Women — Platform for action (Beijing + 10): OJ C 320 E, 15.12.2005; Bull. 3-2005, point 1.3.25

Human rights 12 Bull. EU 1/2-2006 Adopted on 2 February. Parliament called for men’s violence against women to be regarded as the main impediment to efforts to overcome inequality between women and men and as a vio- lation of human rights, reflecting unequal gender power relations. The Parliament asked the Com- mission and Member States to adopt an all- encompassing policy approach to combat vio- lence against women, including effective methods of prevention and punishment. It called on Mem- ber States to establish partnership schemes between law-enforcement authorities, NGOs, refuges for victims and other appropriate author- ities, to intensify cooperation to ensure the effec- tive implementation of existing laws, and to raise the awareness of issues relating to men’s violence against women. 1.4.5. Proposal for a European Parliament and Council recommendation on the protection of minors and human dignity and the right of reply in relation to the competitiveness of the European audiovisual and information services industry ( → point 1.13.9). 1.4.6. European Economic and Social Commit- tee opinion on the Commission communication on the implementation, results and overall assess- ment of the European Year of People with Dis- abilities 2003 (submitted by the Commission in accordance with Article 13 of Council Decision 2001/903/EC) ( → point 1.7.10). General 1.4.7. Proposal for a Council regulation estab- lishing a European Union Agency for Funda- mental Rights; proposal for a Council decision empowering the agency to pursue its activities in areas referred to in Title VI of the Treaty on European Union . Regulation to be repealed: Council Regulation (EC) No 1035/97 establishing a European Moni- toring Centre on Racism and Xenophobia: OJ L 151, 10.6.1997; Bull. 6-1997, point 1.2.3 Commission proposal: COM(2005) 280; Bull. 6- 2005, point 1.2.2 European Economic and Social Committee opin- ion delivered on 14 February. The Committee congratulated the European Council on its deci- sion to create a European Agency for Funda- mental Rights. It was nevertheless concerned by the fact that the proposal does not favour a large representation of civil society within the agency’s board of management and its forum of funda- mental rights. The Committee recommended that one of the agency’s main objectives be to formu- late recommendations which the institutions, organs, offices and agencies could use to adopt measures and formulate actions in the area of fundamental rights. It also underlined that the agency should be encouraged by the European Parliament, the Council or the Commission to determine the compatibility between the Charter of Fundamental Rights and all new legislative proposals or community policy. It also high- lighted that the agency’s thematic action areas, in the context of the multi-annual programme, should always include issues such as the fight against racism and xenophobia. The Committee also stressed the importance for the agency to remain independent from European institutions and Member States. Actions outside the European Union 1.4.8. European Parliament resolution on strate- gies to prevent the trafficking of women and chil- dren who are vulnerable to sexual exploitation. References: Decision No 293/2000/EC of the European Par- liament and of the Council adopting a programme of Community action (the Daphne programme) (2000–03) on preventive measures to fight violence against children, young persons and women: OJ L 34, 9.2.2000; Bull. 1/2-2000, point 1.2.3 Charter of Fundamental Rights: OJ C 364, 18.12.2000; Bull. 12-2000, point 1.2.2 Council Framework Decision 2002/629/JHA on combating trafficking in human beings: OJ L 203, 1.8.2002; Bull. 7/8-2002, point 1.4.4 Council Framework Decision 2004/68/JHA on combating the sexual exploitation of children and child pornography: OJ L 13, 20.1.2004; Bull. 12- 2003, point 1.4.17 Regulation (EC) No 806/2004 of the European Parliament and of the Council on promoting gen- der equality in development cooperation: OJ L 143, 30.4.2004; Bull. 3-2004, point 1.6.59 Council Directive 2004/81/EC on the residence permit issued to third-country nationals who are victims of trafficking in human beings or who have been the subject of an action to facilitate illegal immigration, who cooperate with the competent authorities: OJ L 261, 6.8.2004; Bull. 4-2004, point 1.4.12

Human rights Bull. EU 1/2-2006 13 Adopted on 17 January. Parliament called for the EU to set visible and credible targets to drasti- cally reduce the number of victims of trafficking over the next 10 years. It noted that the penalties for the sexual exploitation of women and chil- dren in Member States have still not been har- monised, despite the adoption of Framework Decision 2002/629/JHA on combating trafficking in human beings, and that trafficking is the fastest-growing criminal activity in comparison with other forms of organised crime. Parliament advocated the building of effective prevention strategies and the development of a coherent action among international organisations and countries, including the review of visa policies in Member States in order to prevent abuse and pro- vide protection against exploitation. It called for measures to be taken to raise awareness amongst vulnerable groups and to combat the use of the Internet to disseminate illegal information. Par- liament also called for the launch of an EU-wide anti-trafficking day and recommended the setting- up of international helplines. 1.4.9. European Parliament resolution on disabil- ity and development ( → point 1.28.5). 1.4.10. European Parliament resolution on the human rights and democracy clause in European Union agreements. References: Parliament resolution on the Commission com- munication on the inclusion of respect for demo- cratic principles and human rights in agreements between the Community and third countries: OJ C 319, 28.10.1996; Bull. 9-1996, point 1.2.8 Parliament resolution on the Commission com- munication on the European Union’s role in pro- moting human rights and democratisation in third countries: OJ C 131 E, 5.6.2003; Bull. 4-2002, point 1.2.5 European Parliament resolution on reinvigorat- ing EU actions on human rights and democratisa- tion with Mediterranean partners: OJ C 97 E, 22.4.2004; Bull. 1/2-2004, point 1.2.10 Partnership agreement between the African, Caribbean and Pacific States, of the one part, and the European Community and its Member States, of the other part (Cotonou Agreement): OJ L 317, 15.12.2000; Bull. 6-2000, point 1.6.83, last amended by the agreement amending the partner- ship agreement signed in Cotonou on 23 June 2000: OJ L 287, 28.10.2005; Bull. 6-2005, point 1.6.73 Adopted on 14 February. Parliament called for the human rights and democracy clause in the agreements of the European Union with third countries to be improved and for it to be gener- ally extended to all countries and all kinds of agreements, including trade and sector-specific agreements. Parliament believes this move would contribute to the eradication of poverty and pro- mote democracy and human rights, ensure reci- procity of the clause, prevent the practice of a double standards policy depending on the impor- tance of the partner and allow Parliament to play its role fully in the implementation of the clause. Parliament pledged to no longer give its assent to agreements that do not comprise the clause on human rights and democracy. It also considered that, with countries covered by EU neighbour- hood policy, the EU should sign agreements going further, based on the sharing of institutions and common values. 1.4.11. European Parliament resolution on the right to freedom of expression and respect for religious beliefs. Adopted on 16 February. In the aftermath of the violence resulting from the publication of car- toons of the prophet Mohammed in the European media, Parliament underlined that freedom of expression is a fundamental value of the EU. It also pointed out that freedom of expression must be exercised within the limits of the law and should coexist with personal responsibility and be based on respect for others’ rights and sensi- bilities. It acknowledged that balancing these con- cerns should stimulate an ongoing democratic debate and it strongly condemned the recent vio- lent protests in certain Muslim countries. Belarus 1.4.12. European Parliament resolution on the sit- uation in Belarus prior to the presidential elec- tions on 19 March ( → point 1.32.26). 1.4.13. Council conclusions on Belarus ( → point 1.32.25). Cambodia 1.4.14. European Parliament resolution on polit- ical repression in Cambodia.

Human rights 14 Bull. EU 1/2-2006 References: Cooperation agreement between the European Community and the Kingdom of Cambodia: OJ L 269, 19.10.1999; Bull. 11-1999, point 1.5.87 European Parliament resolution on the traffick- ing of women and children in Cambodia: OJ C 247 E, 6.10.2005; Bull. 1/2-2005, point 1.2.3 European Parliament resolution on Cambodia: OJ C 320, 15.12.2005; Bull. 3-2005, point 1.2.5 European Parliament resolution on the human rights situation in Cambodia, Laos and Vietnam: Bull. 12-2005, point 1.2.1 Adopted on 19 January. Parliament highlighted concerns at recent arrests and legal proceedings in Cambodia, concerned that such incidents fall foul of the government’s pledges to donors and local people to build a more open, democratic and fair society. The constant arrests of opposition leaders, trade union leaders, journalists and rep- resentatives of NGOs send an unfortunate mes- sage to donors, Parliament explained, calling on the EU to continue its financial support to help improve the human rights situation. Parliament called on the country to respect its international obligations, including the cooperation agreement with the EU, and repeated its desire for a special Parliament delegation to be sent to Cambodia. The Parliament also called for all charges to be dropped against human rights activists. Cuba 1.4.15. European Parliament resolution on the European Union’s policy towards the Cuban government. References: Common Position 96/697/CFSP adopted by the Council on the basis of Article J.2 of the Treaty on European Union concerning Cuba: OJ C 322, 12.12.1996; Bull. 12-1996, point 1.4.91 European Parliament resolution on Cuba: OJ C 201 E, 18.8.05; Bull. 11-2004, point 1.2.3 European Parliament resolution on the ‘Annual report on human rights in the world 2004’ and the EU’s policy on the matter: Bull. 4-2005, point 1.2.2 Adopted on 2 February. Parliament regretted the absence of any significant signs on the part of the Cuban authorities in response to the European Union’s calls for full respect for fundamental freedoms, especially freedom of expression and political association. It condemned the worsen- ing repression and the increase in the number of prisoners of conscience. It also condemned the travel ban on the ‘Damas de blanco’, the wors- ening repression against the peaceful opposition and the fresh wave of imprisonments. Egypt 1.4.16. European Parliament resolution on Egypt: violence against Sudanese refugees ( → point 1.4.16). Peru 1.4.17. European Parliament resolution on Peru. Adopted on 19 January. Parliament congratulated Chilean and Peruvian authorities on the effec- tiveness of their cooperation in the arrest of Mr Fujimori. The former Peruvian president (who was in power from 1990 to 2000) had been wanted for human rights violations and corrup- tion. The Parliament has called on Peruvian authorities to ensure full witness protection in the Fujimori trial. Russia 1.4.18. European Parliament resolution on Chech- nya after the elections and civil society in Russia ( → point 1.4.18). United States 1.4.19. European Parliament resolution on Guantánamo. References: Parliament resolution on the detainees in Guan- tánamo Bay: OJ C 284 E, 21.11.2002; Bull. 1/2- 2002, point 1.2.5 European Parliament recommendation to the Council on the Guantánamo detainees’ right to a fair trial: OJ C 102 E, 28.4.2004; Bull. 3-2004, point 1.2.6 Adopted on 16 February. Parliament called on the United States government to close down the Guan- tánamo Bay detention centre. It also condemned all forms of torture and ill-treatment and reiterated the need to comply with international law.

Human rights Bull. EU 1/2-2006 15 Zimbabwe 1.4.20. Council decision 2006/114/EC extending the period of application of the measures in Deci- sion 2002/148/EC concluding consultations with Zimbabwe under Article 96 of the ACP–EC part- nership agreement ( → point 1.32.94). Financing of operations to promote democracy and human rights 1.4.21. Communication from the Commission to the Council and the European Parliament entitled ‘Thematic programme for the promotion of democracy and human rights worldwide under the future financial perspectives 2007–13’. References: Regulation (EC) No 2240/2004 of the European Parliament and of the Council amending Council Regulation (EC) No 975/1999 laying down the requirements for the implementation of develop- ment cooperation operations which contribute to the general objective of developing and consolidat- ing democracy and the rule of law and to that of respecting human rights and fundamental freedoms: OJ L 390, 31.12.2004; Bull. 12-2004, point 1.2.4 Council Regulation (EC) No 2242/2004 amend- ing Regulation (EC) No 976/1999 laying down the requirements for the implementation of Commu- nity operations, other than those of development cooperation, which, within the framework of Com- munity cooperation policy, contribute to the gen- eral objective of developing and consolidating democracy and the rule of law, and to that of respecting human rights and fundamental freedoms in third countries: OJ L 390, 31.12.2004; Bull. 12- 2004, point 1.2.5 Commission communication ‘External actions through thematic programmes under the future finan- cial perspectives 2007–13’: OJ C 236, 24.9.2005; COM(2005) 324; Bull. 7/8-2005, point 1.7.2 Adopted on 25 January. The Commission pro- posed a thematic programme for the promotion of democracy and human rights worldwide to fol- low on from the present European initiative for democracy and human rights (EIDHR), the legal basis for which will expire by the end of 2006. Council conclusions on the quality of pub- lic finances. Adopted on 24 January . The Council welcomed the report prepared by the Economic Policy Committee (EPC) on challenges and progress made in improving the quality of public expen- diture. While underlining that the composition of public finances, budgetary laws, fiscal frame- works and institutions are issues of national responsibility, the Council acknowledged the increasing importance of the quality of public finances in national and EU economic policy- making. The Council also stressed the importance of further improving efficiency and effectiveness of public spending in order to enhance the qual- ity of public finances. It called on the EPC to fur- ther develop the measurement of public expendi- ture efficiency by assisting Member States in improving the information content of budgets and exchanging of best practices in the evaluation of public spending. Finally, the Council agreed to come back to these issues in the autumn of 2006. 1.5.2. European Economic and Social Commit- tee own-initiative opinion entitled ‘Broad guide- lines for economic policies — GOPE (2005–08)’. Reference: Integrated guidelines for growth and jobs (2005–08) including a Commission recom- mendation on the broad guidelines for the eco- nomic policies of the Member States and the Com- munity (under Article 99 of the EC Treaty): OJ C 125, 24.5.2005; COM(2005) 141; Bull. 4-2005, point 1.1.5 Adopted at its session of 15 and 16 February. In the current context of persistently weak growth affecting the euro area and faced with the chal- lenges of globalisation and demographic changes, the Committee underlined the necessity to set up a coordinated macropolicy. It believes, as does the Commission, that Member States should adopt a budget policy which is concurrent to their commitments so as to mitigate the confidence cri- sis affecting the larger euro area economies. The Committee also supported the Commission when it called for the modernisation of the social secu- rity systems, in order to ensure their viability and to make it possible for social partners and for the governments of Member States to reach a balance between flexibility and safety which is favourable to innovation. It believed that a macroeconomic policy is just as important as microeconomic reforms are necessary in order to increase growth potential, keeping in mind that the maximum degree of market integration does not correspond in all cases to the optimal level of integration. Lastly, regarding the knowledge society, the Committee considered that it is extremely impor- tant to establish suitable orientations in the fields of education and lifelong training, equal oppor- tunities, aid for the family, education, and research and innovation. Moreover, the Commit- tee underlined the need to pay particular atten- tion to promote entrepreneurship. Stability and Growth Pact General 1.5.3. Council opinion in accordance with Arti- cle 5(3) of Council Regulation (EC) No 1466/97 of 7 July 1997 on the updated stability pro- gramme of Belgium, 2005–09. Reference: Council opinion in accordance with Arti- cle 5(3) of Council Regulation (EC) No 1466/97, on the updated stability programme of Belgium, 2004–08: OJ C 136, 3.6.2005; SEC(2005) 143; Bull. 1/2-2005, point 1.3.11 Recommendation adopted by the Commission on 1 February. SEC(2006) 108 Adopted by the Council on 14 February. The Council considered the updated stability pro- gramme of Belgium, covering the period from 2005 to 2009, to be broadly in line with the requirements of the revised code of conduct on the content and format of stability and conver- gence programmes. Based on a plausible macro- economic scenario, the programme aims at keep- ing the general government budget in balance until 2006 and in growing surplus thereafter. It largely confirms the budgetary strategy outlined in the previous programme. The Belgian author- ities have set the medium-term objective (MTO) for the budgetary position at a surplus of 0.5% of GDP in structural terms (i.e. cyclically adjusted and net of one-off and temporary meas- ures). While the budgetary outcomes could be worse than targeted in the programme, the Bel- gian authorities have demonstrated a strong com- mitment to achieving their balanced budget tar- gets in the past. The budgetary stance may not be sufficient to reach the MTO by 2007 (as planned) but ensures an appropriate structural position as well as a safety margin against breaching the 3% of GDP deficit threshold with normal macroeconomic fluctuations in each year. The adjustment path can be considered as broadly appropriate in view of the ambitious MTO, except in 2006 when the structural bal- ance is planned to deteriorate. The debt ratio is planned to decline from 94% of GDP in 2005 to less than 80% in 2009 and approaches the 60% reference value at a rapid pace. As regards long- term sustainability, Belgium is at medium risk on grounds of the projected budgetary costs of ageing populations. The Council called on Bel- gium to consider taking measures in order to avoid deteriorating the structural balance in 2006 and to implement measures necessary in order to achieve ambitious budgetary objectives in the following years.

Adopted on 27 February. The Commission con- sidered that the first step towards improving the security of the entire supply chain is needed. It considered, in view of the size and complexities of the market, that a voluntary, but controlled framework for land transport supply chain secu- rity is the most appropriate course of action. The Commission’s proposed action plan identifies five main areas that will map out future initiatives in this field. The first of these is the upgrading of existing minimum standards for animal protec- tion and welfare in line with new scientific evi- dence and socioeconomic assessments as well as the possibility of elaborating specific minimum standards for species or issues that are not cur- rently addressed in EU legislation. The second area is concerned with giving a high priority to promoting policy-oriented future research on animal protection and welfare and the applica- tion of the 3Rs principle: the principle of replace- ment, reduction and refinement of alternative approaches to animal testing. On the issue of the legal basis, it stated that resorting to a sin- gle legal basis for both public health and consumer protection contradicts the principle of subsidiarity. It also noted that the final budget has yet to be finalised and is dependent on current negotiations on the financial perspective of the EU for the period 2007–13 but that it sees fit that the policy of the EU regarding public health and consumer protection takes financial priority, as it is included in the programme and in the strategy. Bull. EU 1/2-2006 123 28. Development cooperation General policy 1.28.1. Commission communication to the Coun- cil and the European Parliament on investing in people and concerning the thematic programme for human and social development under the financial perspectives for 2007–13. References: Regulation (EC) No 1567/2003 of the European Parliament and of the Council on aid for policies and actions on reproductive and sexual health and rights in developing countries: OJ L 224, 6.9.2003 Regulation (EC) No 1568/2003 of the European Parliament and of the Council on aid to fight poverty diseases (HIV/AIDS, tuberculosis and malaria) in developing countries: OJ L 224, 6.9.2003 Commission communication to the Council and Parliament entitled ‘External actions through the- matic programmes under the future financial per- spective 2007–13’: OJ C 236, 24.9.2005; COM(2005) 324; Bull. 7/8-2005, point 1.7.2 Adopted on 25 January. The Commission pro- poses orientation for the future programming of thematic interventions, complementary to coun- try planning, in the area of human and social development. The proposal identifies six main areas of intervention: good health for all, knowl- edge and skills, employment and social cohe- sion, gender equality, children and youth, and culture. COM(2006) 18 Millennium development goals 1.28.2. Commission decision on the adoption of a memorandum of understanding concerning the creation of a trust fund by the European Invest- ment Bank (EIB) and the European Commission regarding infrastructure in Africa. Reference: Commission communication ‘EU strat- egy forAfrica: towards a Euro-African pact to accel- erate Africa’s development’: OJ C 49, 28.2.2006; COM(2005) 489; Bull. 1/20-2005, point 1.6.24 Adopted on 1 February. The Commission created a trust fund which will operate as a financial tool of the EU–Africa partnership for infrastructure. The fund will target transnational projects, and in particular African energy, water and telecom net- works. The fund’s political objective is to attract additional resources from Member States which have pledged to increase official development assistance in the framework of the millennium development goals. 1.28.3. European Parliament resolution on new financial instruments for development in connec- tion with the millennium goals. Adopted on 16 February. Parliament welcomed the conference to be held in Paris from 28 Feb- ruary to 1 March, which seeks to make progress on the agreement of international levies, with a particular focus on a possible levy on airline tickets. It insisted that any alternative methods of financing for development must bring new, additional funds for development and must not replace official development assistance. Parlia- ment nevertheless regretted the lack of a pre- cise timetable committing all developed coun- tries to the pursuit of the intermediate and final millennium development goals targets and high- lighted that the effectiveness of aid must be improved. Food security and food aid 1.28.4. Communication from the Commission to the Council and the European Parliament con- cerning a thematic strategy for food security enti- tled ‘Advancing the food security agenda to achieve the millennium development goals’. Reference: Commission communication ‘EU strat- egy for Africa: towards a Euro-African pact to accelerate Africa’s development’: OJ C 49, 28.2.2006; COM(2005) 489; Bull. 1/20-2005, point 1.6.24

Development cooperation 124 Bull. EU 1/2-2006 Adopted on 25 January. The Commission pro- vided orientations for the future programming of thematic interventions, complementary to country programming, in the area of food security. It envisaged three main areas of intervention: sup- porting the delivery of international public goods contributing directly to food security and the financing of global programmes; addressing food insecurity in countries or regions where either governments are not in place, or not in control of parts of a country, or no country strategic frame- work is operational; and, finally, promoting inno- vative policies and strategies in the field of food security. The proposal focuses particularly on Africa and has a continental, regional, national and local level. COM(2006) 21 Health, AIDS and population 1.28.5. European Parliament resolution on dis- ability and development. Reference: Commission communication ‘Towards a United Nations legally binding instrument to promote and protect the rights and dignity of per- sons with disabilities’: OJ C 311, 20.12.2003; COM(2003) 16; Bull. 1/2-2003, point 1.3.49 Adopted on 19 January. Parliament stresses that disability issues should be reflected in the Com- mission’s development policies and in its specific programmes. It believes that disability issues must be mainstreamed at all levels, from policy development to implementation and evaluation, and that all actors involved in EU development cooperation activities should be informed about issues relating to disability and the promotion and protection of the fundamental human rights of disabled people in developing countries. Cooperation with NGOs and decentralised cooperation 1.28.8. Communication from the Commission to the Council, the European Parliament, the Euro- pean Economic and Social Committee and the Committee of the Regions on the thematic pro- gramme for ‘non-State actors and local authori- ties in development’. References: Commission communication ‘Participation of non-State actors in EC development policy’: COM(2002) 598; Bull. 11-2002, point 1.6.43 European Parliament resolution on participation of non-State actors in EC development policy: OJ C 76, 25.3.2004; Bull. 9-2003, point 1.6.70 Commission communication to the Council and Parliament ‘External actions through thematic pro- grammes under the future financial perspective 2007–13’: OJ C 236, 24.9.2005; COM(2005) 324; Bull. 7/8-2005, point 1.7.2 Council conclusions ‘European consensus on development’: Bull. 11-2005, point 1.6.34 Adopted on 25 January. The Commission pro- posed a programme intended to be the successor of the current NGO co-financing and decen- tralised cooperation programmes. The programme is ‘actor-oriented’ instead of ‘sector-oriented’. It supports stakeholders’ right of initiative by pro- viding financial resources for their ‘own initia- tives’, when geographical programmes are not the appropriate instrument, and by complementing the support that other ‘sectoral’ thematic programmes can provide to the same actors. Three main areas of intervention were proposed: support for inter- ventions in the field carried out in partner coun- tries, interventions which promote awareness for development and activities which facilitate coor- dination between stakeholders’ networks. References: Council Regulation (EC) No 1260/1999 laying down general provisions on the Structural Funds: OJ L 161, 26.6.1999; Bull. 6-1999, point II.1 Commission communication ‘Wider Europe — Neighbourhood: a new framework for relations with our eastern and southern neighbours’: OJ C 76, 25.3.2004; COM(2003) 104; Bull. 3-2003, point 1.6.79 Commission communication on the European neighbourhood policy — Strategy paper: COM(2004) 373; Bull. 5-2004, point 1.6.56 Commission communication on the Commission proposals for action plans under the European neighbourhood policy (ENP): COM(2004) 795; Bull. 12-2004, point 1.6.77 Adopted on 19 January . The Parliament voted in support of a neighbourhood policy for those European countries which do not, or do not cur- rently have an accession perspective, but seek a closer political and economic relationship with the EU. The Parliament insisted on the European neighbourhood policy being adapted to the needs of the different countries to which it applies and not being a one-size-fits-all policy. The Parlia- ment also supported the idea of sanctions against countries which failed to respect European and international standards, particularly in human rights, considering that, for such countries, the EU should be ready to restrict or suspend Com- munity aid, or even revoke the European neigh- bourhood policy action plan. Furthermore, the Parliament stated that the promotion of human rights, democracy and the rule of law must remain priorities in the ENP action plans drawn up within the framework of this policy. 1.30.2. The European Parlia- ment has criticised the use of violence by the Egyptian police against Sudanese demonstrators in December, and urged the authorities to end their indiscriminate use of force on Sudanese asy- lum seekers, refugees and immigrants. It wel- comed the investigation into the violence by the Egyptian authorities, but has also called for an independent inquiry which would include some United Nations experts. The resolution criticises the failure of the United Nations High Commis- sion for Refugees (UNHCR) to find a solution for the Sudanese refugees, yet recognising the difficulties, urges the European Commission and Member States to establish genuine partnership with the UNHCR, to provide both political and financial support for their work in Cairo. Believ- ing there has been an escalation in the level of human rights violations in Egypt in recent months, the Parliament has repeated its calls for the rights of the leader of the Egyptian opposi- tion, Ayman Nour, who is currently imprisoned on charges of falsifying signatures required for the registration of his political party, to be respected. Parliament commended the determination with which the people of Afghanistan are engaging with peace and estab- lishing democracy. It congratulated the country on the success of the 2004 elections, which was an extraordinary accomplishment, and on the general and local elections of 2005. However, it deplored the fact that eight candidates were killed during the electoral process. Parliament called for the new Afghan government to pursue its efforts concerning good governance and to implement sustainable reforms in favour of gender and eth- nic equality. On this point, it considered the par- ticipation of women in the recent elections as a positive outcome; nevertheless, it said this result could be improved upon. It added that it hopes that the Afghan authorities will be more account- able for development process. On this point, the EU must ensure greater visibility of its actions and financial contributions, since it is the second biggest donor in Afghanistan. In view of the Lon- don conference on international involvement in Afghanistan, the Parliament called for a strategy which lays emphasis on specific objectives, such as respect for human rights, democratic gover- nance and the adoption of a system of balance of power. It also called for a permanent delegation to be established within Parliament to deal with relations with the Afghan Parliament, in order for it to be able to have a positive influence on the democratisation process. The Council welcomed the comprehensive Commission communication on ‘A stronger partnership between the European Union and Latin America’ and underlined the EU’s objective to continue to cooperate closely with Latin America to promote common values and interests, and to contribute jointly to peace and security, protection and promotion of human rights as well as to the strengthening of citizen’s participation and democracy. OJ C 36, 11.2.2006 1.34.10. 13.12.2005: Case C-446/03 Marks & Spencer plc v David Halsey (Her Majesty’s Inspector of Taxes) . As Community law now stands, Articles 43 EC and 48 EC do not preclude provisions of a Member State which generally prevent a resident parent company from deducting from its taxable profits losses incurred in another Member State by a subsidiary established in that Member State although they allow it to deduct losses incurred by a resident subsidiary. However, it is contrary to Articles 43 EC and 48 EC to prevent the resident parent company from doing so where the non- resident subsidiary has exhausted the possibilities available in its State of residence of having the losses taken into account for the accounting period concerned by the claim for relief and also for previous account- ing periods and where there are no possibilities for those losses to be taken into account in its State of res- idence for future periods either by the subsidiary itself or by a third party, in particular where the subsidiary has been sold to that third party. 164 Bull. EU 1/2-2006 35. Community institutions European Parliament Rules of procedure 1.35.1. European Parliament decision on the amendments to be made to the European Parlia- ment’s rules of procedure relating to standards for the conduct of Members of the European Parliament. Adopted on 19 January. Given the repeated inci- dents which occur mainly, but not exclusively, in the Parliament’s principal chamber, the Parlia- ment has adopted a decision amending its rules of procedure. It specifies the standard of behaviour expected of its members, and also defines the possible consequences related to the violation of this behaviour, this in order to guarantee the smooth conduct of parliamentary business and preserve the dignity of the Parliament as both a European Union institution and a parliamentary assembly. Strasbourg, 16 to 19 January 1.35.2. The highlights of this session were the presentation of the programme of the Austrian Presidency and the adoption of the report on the period of reflection: structure, subjects and con- text for an assessment of the debate on the Euro- pean Union. The Commission and the Council made a declaration on the topical issue of ‘secu- rity of energy supplies, particularly gas’. The Parliament gave its view on the financial per- spective 2007–13 rejecting the European Coun- cil’s common position in its current form. It also rejected the proposal for a directive of the Euro- pean Parliament and of the Council on market access to port services. The Parliament made two written declarations, the first on the farming of bear bile in China ( → point 1.23.4) and the second concerning the child helplines in Europe ( → point 1.4.1). It also took three decisions; one on setting up a com- mittee of inquiry into the collapse of the ‘Equi- table Life Committee of Inquiry’ ( → point 1.9.4); the second setting up a temporary committee on the alleged use of European countries by the CIA for the transportation and illegal detention of pris- oners ( → point 1.4.3); the third on the standards of conduct of Members of the European Parlia- ment (amendment of the rules of procedure) ( → point 1.35.1). In the field of the future of the Union and insti- tutional questions, Parliament adopted a resolu- tion on the structure, subjects and context for an assessment of the debate on the European Union ( → point 1.1.2). On the human rights front , Parliament adopted resolutions on combating the trafficking of women and children who are vulnerable to sex- ual exploitation ( → point 1.4.8); on homophobia in Europe ( → point 1.4.2); on Peru ( → point 1.4.17); on Cambodia ( → point 1.4.14). In the field of the Community economic and social area, Parliament adopted resolutions on the implementation of the European charter for small enterprises ( → point 1.11.1); on the future of the Lisbon strategy from a gender perspective ( → point 1.8.2). In the field of citizenship and the quality of life, Parliament adopted resolutions on developing the agenda for the Community’s external aviation policy ( → point 1.21.17); on the relations with Russia and China in the field of air transport ( → point 1.21.18); on climate change ( → point 1.20.17); on the environmental aspects of sus- tainable development strategy ( → point 1.20.5); Parliament rejected the motion for a resolution on the Commission’s fourth report on citizenship of the Union. On the role of the Union in the world, Parliament adopted resolutions on Afghanistan ( → point 1.32.49); on Chechnya after the elections and civil society in Russia ( → point 1.32.35); on the

Council Institutional affairs 1.35.5 . Council Decision modifying the internal regulation of the Council: weighting of votes. Adopted by the Council on 23 January. This deci- sion modifies the Council’s rules of procedure in order to update the table on the populations of European Union Member States for 2006 for the purposes of qualified majority voting in the Council. The Council’s rules of procedure pro- vide that when a decision is to be adopted by the Council by a qualified majority, and if a member of the Council so requests, it will be verified that the Member States constituting the qualified majority represent at least 62% of the total pop- ulation of the Union.

Commission General Report on the Activities of the European Union 1.35.16. General Report on the Activities of the European Union over 2005. Previous report: Bull. 1/2-2005, point 1.1.20 Adopted on 31 January. Presented to the Mem- bers of the European Parliament and communi- cated to the other institutions, the General Report 2005 outlines the activities of the European Union (EU) during the past year. This document provides a comprehensive account of the work of all the institutions and bodies of the EU. Its struc- ture is inspired by the four strategic objectives defined by the Commission to guide its own work programme: prosperity, solidarity, security and role of the Union as a world partner. There is an additional chapter devoted specifically to the institutional dimension. Within this framework, and by briefly identifying the principal develop- ments of dossiers during the previous year, the General Report highlights the headlines and key developments in the life of the EU in 2005. Pub- lished in the twenty official languages of the EU, the General Report is available for purchase from the various sales offices of the official publica- tions of the European Communities. It is also accessible on the Internet via the Europa server: (http://europa.eu.int/abc/doc/off/rg/en/welcome. htm).
